Sci.name: Ulmus americana
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 50-70

Tree Height (ft): 70-90 

Growth Rate: fast

Pest Risk: bark beetles, elm borer, gypsy moth, mites, and scales

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: they produce many seeds, which can create a mess on pavement; shallow but extensive roots. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Ostrya virginiana
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 25-30

Tree Height (ft): 30-40

Growth Rate: slow

Pest Risk: no pests of this tree are usually serious

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: Little pruning required.

Sci.name: Acer ginnala
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 20-25

Tree Height (ft): 20-30

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: it is well-suited for planting close to power lines since it slows down and remains small at maturity. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Nyssa sylvatica
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 25-35

Tree Height (ft): 65-75

Growth Rate: slow

Pest Risk: no pests are normally seen on the tree

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: the small, blue fruits may be considered a litter nuisance in urban/suburban plantings but
are quite popular with many birds and mammals, and they wash away quickly. Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Prunus x. 'autumnalis'
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 25-35

Tree Height (ft): 25-35

Growth Rate: fast

Pest Risk: very sensitive to one or more pests or diseases which can affect tree health or aesthetics; sensitive to aphids, borers, scales, spider mites, and tent caterpillars

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: grows semi-double pink flowers, and has attractive leaf colors in the fall. Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Prunus x. Rosacea 'okame'
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 15-20

Tree Height (ft): 15-20

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: it is one of the most delicate and finest flowering trees available. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Prunus x. yedoensis
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 30-40

Tree Height (ft): 35-45

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: very sensitive to one or more pests or diseases which can affect tree health or aesthetics; sensitive to aphids, borers, scales, spider mites, and tent caterpillars

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: one of two cherry tree species that provides the iconic blooms in Washington, DC. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Celtis occidentalis
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 15-20

Tree Height (ft): 39-60

Growth Rate: fast in favorable soil conditions

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: high

Sci.name: Ginkgo biloba
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 50-60

Tree Height (ft): 50-75

Growth Rate: slow

Pest Risk: no pests are normally seen on the tree

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: the tree is easily transplanted and has a vivid yellow fall color which is second to none in brilliance. Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Koelreuteria paniculata
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 30-40

Tree Height (ft): 30-40

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: it tolerates dryness and casts little shade because of the open growth habit. It makes a good street or parking lot tree, particularly where overhead or soil space is limited, due to its adaptive abilities. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Eucommia ulmoides
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 25-35

Tree Height (ft): 40-60

Growth Rate: slow

Pest Risk: no pests are normally seen on the tree

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: only one or two corrective prunings at an early age normally is all that is needed to develop good structure in the crown. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Acer campestre
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 30-35

Tree Height (ft): 30-35

Growth Rate: slow

Pest Risk: no pests are normally seen on the tree

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: The small stature and vigorous growth make this an excellent street tree for residential areas, or perhaps in downtown urban sites. However, it grows a little too tall for planting beneath some power lines. It is also suitable as a patio or yard shade tree because it stays small and creates dense shade. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Gleditsia triacanthos Inermis
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 35-50

Tree Height (ft): 50-70

Growth Rate: fast

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: the tiny leaflets turn golden yellow in fall before dropping and are so small they easily vanish into the grass below, without any raking being necessary. Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Syringa reticulata
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 15-25

Tree Height (ft): 20-30

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: It is being used as a street tree in some parts of the country, particularly in areas with overhead power lines. Japanese Tree Lilac is also popular as a garden specimen or as an accent in a shrub border. Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Gymnocladus dioicus
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 45-60

Tree Height (ft): 65-70

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: no pests are normally seen on the tree

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: large seed pods hang on the tree in the winter but can be a litter problem when they fall in the spring. Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Tilia cordata
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 40-50

Tree Height (ft): 50-70

Growth Rate: fast

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: it is a prolific bloomer, the small fragrant flowers appearing in late June and into July. Many bees are attracted to the flowers, and the dried flowers persist on the tree for some time.  Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Quercus palustris
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 35-40

Tree Height (ft): 50-75

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: the straight trunk and small, well-attached branches make Pin Oak an extremely safe tree to plant in urban areas. Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Acer rubrum
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 25-35

Tree Height (ft): 60-75

Growth Rate: fast

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: When planting the species Acer rubrum, select only those which have been grown from seed sources in your area. The seeds of red maple are quite popular with squirrels and birds. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Quercus rubra
Description:
Canopy Spread: 50 to 60 feet

Tree Height: 60 to 70 feet

Growth Rate: fast

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: moderate


Other: Like most other large-sized trees, roots can heave sidewalks. Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Quercus acutissima
Description:
Canopy Spread: 35 to 50 feet

Tree Height: 35 to 45 feet

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: Like most other large-sized trees, roots can heave sidewalks. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Amelanchier x grandiflora
Description: (link/image is Amelanchier canadensis, not this cultivar...)

Sci.name: Quercus imbricaria
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 40-60

Tree Height (ft): 40-60

Growth Rate: slow

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: its pyramidal shape when young help to make it suited to use as a screen, or a durable street or specimen tree which is unlikely to be damaged by harsh winds or snow-loads. Requires little pruning.

Sci.name: Tilia tomentosa
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 40-60

Tree Height (ft): 50-70

Growth Rate: fast

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: moderate

Other: a good shade and street tree; the flowers attract large numbers of bees. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Sophora japonica
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 40-70

Tree Height (ft): 40-70

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: Highly recommended for urban street tree planting. It has a rapid growth rate and tolerates polluted city conditions, heat, and drought. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.

Sci.name: Zelkova serrata
Description:
Canopy Spread (ft): 50-75

Tree Height (ft): 55-80

Growth Rate: medium

Pest Risk: long-term health usually not affected by pests

Drought Tolerance: high

Other: Established trees are fairly drought-tolerant, requiring little irrigation unless located in sandy soil. It makes a wonderful street tree even in restricted-soil tree pits, and is almost pest free. The crowns will eventually grow together if trees are planted on 30-foot-centers, forming a wonderful shaded street. This is a tough, urban tree which is often planted along streets in downtown and residential areas. Requires pruning to develop strong structure.
